Award.AwardTitle: Hardy/BMO spaces and Fourier Multipliers in the Noncommutative Setting
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project aims to develop an abstract theory of Hardy/BMO spaces and Fourier multipliers, particularly within a noncommutative framework. Semigroups of operators will be used crucially to make up for the lack of geometric/metric structure and the lack of a commutative product in the abstract setting. The new insights gained from this work should also reflect back on noncommutative geometry, operator space theory, and classical harmonic analysis.

The study of noncommutative objects offers a new point of view on many topics in mathematics that reflect daily life, and it also arguably represents the "right" language for quantum mechanics. In real life, the order in which certain operations are executed can make a big difference. For example, first boiling water and afterwards adding oil is very different from first boiling oil and then adding water. Noncommutative analysis is about functions and their properties in the realm of noncommuting variables. The most important example is matrix-valued functions. The theory of Fourier analysis or harmonic analysis has a lot to say about functions, and as this project intends to show, also about matrix-valued functions. The project will also make valuable contributions to control theory and signal and image processing, where matrix-valued functions are natural occurences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The  PI continues his investigation in   noncommutative harmonic analysis and its applications. The PI studied  Fourier multipliers, Dirac Operators, Pisier's OUMD property, H1-BMO duality, and unconditional sequences of group von Neumann algebras. 

 The PI reinvented several classical tools, e.g.  BMO spaces Semigroups of operators and 1-cocycle, in the so called "noncommutative" context where the space has  less nice structures.  The PI proved the boundedness of free Hilbert transforms and heat semigroups of operators on hyperbolic groups. This solves a long standing problem asked by P. Biane and G. Pisier, and implicitly answers a compactness-question raised by N. Ozawa. 

These results improved the understanding of operator spaces/operator algebras and strengthened the existing link between mathematics and physics.    The project made valuable contributions to the understanding of  statistics and engenerine, e.g. the control theory. These results are published in the following two articles.

 [MR17] T. Mei, E. Ricard, Free Hilbert transforms, Duke Mathematical Journal,  166 (2017), no. 11, 2153-2182. 


 [MS17] T. Mei and M. de la Salle, Complete boundedness of Heat Semigroups on the von Neumann Algebra of hyperbolic groups,  Transactions of the American Math. Society,  369 (2017), no. 8, 5601-5622.

The PI has been training a PhD student ChianYeong Chua at Baylor University.
